student_data.notes: Data sourced from the UNM School of Engineering 'Facts and Figures' Fall 2023 enrollment report. Undergrad count refers to BS Computer Science students. Grad counts refer to MS and PhD specifically in Computer Science. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: The 'Bohr' cluster is a condo model containing heterogeneous nodes owned by individual PIs. While it contains GPU nodes, the exact specifications and counts are not publicly enumerated on the center's status page.

gpu_resources.notes:
Counts derived from the Center for Advanced Research Computing (CARC) 'Resources' page.

1) Xena Cluster: 28 nodes × 2 NVIDIA V100S (32GB) GPUs = 56 V100s.

UNM is a partner in the 'ACES' cluster (Intel/Dell/Nvidia H100 testbed), but this is an NSF resource hosted at Texas A&M and not owned/operated exclusively by UNM, therefore it is excluded from this count. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

analysis_notes: UNM centralized computing (CARC) relies primarily on the Xena cluster for GPU workloads. Newer hardware (A100/H100) does not appear in the public inventory of the central facility, though it may exist in private PI groups (Bohr cluster) or via access to the ACES consortium (external).
